SlimFL: Federated Learning with Superposition Coding over Slimmable Neural Networks

Won Joon Yun, Yunseok Kwak, Hankyul Baek, Soyi Jung,  Mingyue Ji, 
Mehdi Bennis,  Jihong Park,  and Joongheon Kim Preliminary version of this paper was accepted to IEEE Conference on Computer Communications (INFOCOM), May 2022 [1].This research is supported by the National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF-Korea, 2022R1A2C2004869) and the Institute of Information & communications Technology Planning & Evaluation (IITP) grant funded by the Korea government (MSIT) (No. 2021-0-00467, Intelligent 6G Wireless Access System). Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is a key enabler for efficient communication and computing, leveraging devices’ distributed computing capabilities. However, applying FL in practice is challenging due to the local devices’ heterogeneous energy, wireless channel conditions, and non-independently and identically distributed (non-IID) data distributions. To cope with these issues, this paper proposes a novel learning framework by integrating FL and width-adjustable slimmable neural networks (SNN). Integrating FL with SNNs is challenging due to time-varying channel conditions and data distributions. In addition, existing multi-width SNN training algorithms are sensitive to the data distributions across devices, which makes SNN ill-suited for FL. Motivated by this, we propose a communication and energy-efficient SNN-based FL (named SlimFL) that jointly utilizes superposition coding (SC) for global model aggregation and superposition training (ST) for updating local models. By applying SC, SlimFL exchanges the superposition of multiple-width configurations decoded as many times as possible for a given communication throughput. Leveraging ST, SlimFL aligns the forward propagation of different width configurations while avoiding inter-width interference during backpropagation. We formally prove the convergence of SlimFL. The result reveals that SlimFL is not only communication-efficient but also deals with non-IID data distributions and poor channel conditions, which is also corroborated by data-intensive simulations.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, Heterogeneous devices, Slimmable neural network

I Introduction

I-A Background and Motivation

Recent advances in machine learning (ML), and hardware technologies have pushed deep learning down from cloud servers to edge devices such as phones, cars, and the Internet of things (IoT) devices [2, 3]. These edge devices collectively constitute a source of ever-growing big data, so are indispensable for training high-quality machine learning models. Meanwhile, each edge device stores only a tiny fraction of the big data, which is often privacy-sensitive (e.g., navigation history, e-Health wearable records, and surveillance camera photos). To exploit these opportunities and address the challenges induced by edge devices, federated learning (FL) is a promising solution that allows edge devices to train a global model by exchanging locally trained models instead of raw data [4, 5, 6, 7].

At its core, FL operations rest on repeatedly constructing a global model averaged over the local models, which is downloaded by each device to replace its local model with the new global model. By design, FL necessitates the use of a single global model for all devices. This requirement restricts the scalability and accuracy of FL, particularly when scaling to the sheer number of edge devices, which have non-identical memory resources and energy budgets not to be mentioned as different communication channel conditions. Therefore, the use of a single large model may be suited for only a few devices, whereas the use of a tiny model should be accompanied by compromising accuracy.

In light of the aforementioned issues in communication-energy efficiencies and scalability, the recently proposed slimmable neural network (SNN) architectures have great potential in that an SNN can adjust its model width in accordance with its available energy budget or task difficulty. Inspired from this, in this article, we propose an SNN-based FL algorithm that makes use of superposition coding (SC) and successive decoding (SD), coined slimmable FL (SlimFL). To illustrate the effectiveness of SlimFL, consider an SNN with two width configurations, as seen in Fig. 1. Each device uploads its local updates during the uplink to the server after jointly encoding the left-half (LH) and right-half (RH) of its local SNN model and assigning distinct transmission power levels, i.e., SC [8]. The server then makes an attempt to decode the LH. If the LH is successfully decoded, the server attempts to decode the RH consecutively, i.e., SD, also known as successive interference cancellation (SIC). As a result, when the device-server channel throughput is poor, the server decodes only the LH of the uploaded model, yielding a model with a half-width (0.5x) width. When the channel has a high throughput, the server may decode both LH and RH and combine them to produce the full-width model (1.0x). As a result, the server creates a global model superimposing the decoded 0.5x and 1.0x local models, which each device downloads. The device substitutes the downloaded global model for its local model and repeats the preceding step until convergence. In addition, the same technique may be extended to the server-to-device downlink.

SlimFL’s efficacy is contingent upon achieving synergy between several width configurations, namely 0.5x and 1.0x models, which is a difficult task. The existing FL algorithm does not focus on synergetic of 0.5x and 1.0x. In addition, since the local model has various width configurations, training them may conflict with one another. To the best of our knowledge, FL with different width configurations have not been proposed, yet. Existing SNN architectures and training techniques are designed for standalone learning and so are unsuitable for SlimFL, especially when data distributions are not independent and identical (non-IID). To address these issues in SlimFL, we provide a new SNN architecture and training method called superposition training (ST), as well as a study of SlimFL’s convergence and efficiency.

I-B Contributions

The major contributions of this paper are summarized as follows.

  • •

    We first propose an FL framework for SNNs, SlimFL (see Fig. 1 and Algorithm 4), which uses SC for enhancing communication efficiency under time-varying wireless channels with limited bandwidth.

  • •

    We develop a local SNN training method for SlimFL, ST (see Algorithm 3), which minimizes excessive inter-width interference and achieves fast convergence with good accuracy while being agnostic to data distribution.

  • •

    We prove the convergence of SlimFL (see Theorem 1). Numerical results show the benefits of SlimFL in terms of channel quality and data distributions and characterize the optimum transmit power allocation for SC (see Proposition 1), and the optimal ST ratio allocation (see Proposition 2).

  • •

    We verify our analysis via simulations, indicating that SlimFL achieves higher accuracy and lower communication costs than vanilla FL (i.e., FedAvg) under poor channel conditions and non-IID data distributions.

In our previous work [1], we only described the brief idea of SlimFL and provided the proof sketches of convergence. In this work, we delineate the detailed operations and motivation of SlimFL, while elaborating on the full derivation steps of the convergence proofs. To further advocate the feasibility of SlimFL under various scenarios, we numerically study the impacts of different channel models, datasets, and local training capabilities in Sec. VI-D.

I-C Organization

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Sec. II describes previous research results of FL and background knowledge of superposition coding and successive decoding. Sec. III presents the proposed SNN model and its training method (i.e., SUSTrain), and Sec. IV designs SlimFL using superposition coding, and successive decoding, Sec. V shows the convergence analysis on SlimFL. Sec. VI presents the simulation-based performance evaluation and its result regarding SlimFL. Finally, Sec. VII concludes this paper.

The notations used in this paper are listed in Table I.

II Related Work

II-A Energy-Constrained Federated Learning

In FL, each edge device trains its model with its own data. After training, all parameters of each local model are transmitted to the server (e.g., cloud, fog, or edge). The server reconstructs the global model by aggregating the local model parameters. FL is privacy-preserving because the device does not transmit its own data to the server. FL has advantages regarding communication/computing costs as well as privacy-preserving. For example, Federated Averaging (FedAvg) reduces 10-100x of communication costs compared to the existing distributed machine learning algorithm [9, 4]. In addition, FL with local batch normalization (FedBN [10]), FL with a generalization and re-parametrization (FedProx [11]), or adaptative aggregation (FedOpt [12]) improves the speed of convergence of the FL regime, which means reducing more communication/computing costs through training algorithms. However, the reduced communication/computing cost is non-negligible, because the communication cost is proportional to the model size. To cope with this problem, one approach is to optimize resource allocation [13, 14]. The other approach is split learning [15], which reduces communication costs by transmitting smashed data rather than model parameters. The other option is to investigate deep learning technique, e.g., model pruning to satisfy varying on-device energy and memory limits [16] or to distill the knowledge of a big trained model into a small empty model through knowledge distillation (KD) [17], but this requires extra training operations. Alternatively, one may alter the width and/or depth of a trained model to match the resource needs. After training, depth-controlled neural networks [18] and adaptive neural networks [19] can modify their depths, while SNNs alter their widths [20]. According to studies [21, 20, 22], many SNN architectures and their algorithms are proposed. In this paper, we leverage width-controllable SNNs, and develop its FL version, SlimFL. Such an extension is non-trivial and entails several design issues, such as local SNN training algorithms, aggregating segment prioritization.

II-B Superposition Coding & Successive Decoding

Non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) often outperforms orthogonal multiple access (OMA) in terms of sum rate and outage probability [23, 24, 25]. While uplink NOMA leverages distance and/or power differences to support more devices [26, 27], downlink NOMA commonly focuses on simultaneously broadcasting multiple signals with different priorities, such that the higher priority signal is more likely to be successfully decoded. Namely, the base station in downlink NOMA superimposes distinct data signals over the same radio block (i.e., SC) by assigning different transmit power levels [8]. The mobile user decodes the SC-encoded signal through successive interference cancellation that decodes the strongest signal first, followed by decoding the next strongest signal after removing the decoded signal (i.e., SD) [28].

Inspired from downlink NOMA, in this paper we apply SC and SD for the uplink operations of SlimFL. Precisely, SlimFL prioritizes an SNN’s LH to obtain the 0.5x model across inferior channels. SlimFL is capable of decoding the RH of the SNN only under favorable the channel circumstances, yielding the 1.0x model by merging both LH and RH. As a result, SlimFL provides consistent convergence even in the presence of weak channels.

III SNN Model Architecture and Training

Currently, available SNN architectures and training algorithms are optimized for standalone learning [20]. This section presents SNN architecture for SlimFL, and its local training.

III-A Operations of Slimmable Neural Network

Lightweight deep learning techniques have been studied widely. Thus many complicated models are distributed to mobile devices via quantization, e.g., TensorRT [29]. Nevertheless, training models in mobile devices still requires computational cost as same as the existing methods. We utilize SNNs as both devices and server models. The key idea of SNN is to reduce floating point operations per second (FLOPS) by activating the selected weights. We compare the existing NN operation to SNN’s. Suppose that input and output pairs are denoted as 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} and 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v}, respectively. The linear operation is written as follows:

𝐯=𝐖⋅𝐰+𝐛,𝐯⋅𝐖𝐰𝐛\mathbf{v}=\mathbf{W}\cdot\mathbf{w}+\mathbf{b}, (1)

where 𝐖𝐖\mathbf{W}, 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b} denote |𝐯|×|𝐰|𝐯𝐰|\mathbf{v}|\times|\mathbf{w}| sized matrix and |𝐯|𝐯|\mathbf{v}| sized vector, respectively. Compared to linear operation, the slimmable linear operation utilizes the shrink ratio is denoted as r∈ℝ​[0,1]𝑟ℝ01r\in\mathbb{R}[0,1] to reduce FLOPS. In the linear operation, the output dimension is reduced by zero-masking 𝐖𝐖\mathbf{W} and 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b}. The following masked weights and biases are obtained as follows:

𝐖masked,r=𝖬𝖺𝗌𝗄​(𝐖,r),𝐛masked,r=𝖬𝖺𝗌𝗄​(𝐛,r),formulae-sequencesubscript𝐖masked𝑟𝖬𝖺𝗌𝗄𝐖𝑟subscript𝐛masked𝑟𝖬𝖺𝗌𝗄𝐛𝑟\mathbf{W}_{\text{masked},r}=\mathsf{Mask}(\mathbf{W},r),\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \mathbf{b}_{\text{masked},r}=\mathsf{Mask}(\mathbf{b},r), (2)

where 𝖬𝖺𝗌𝗄​(𝐖,r)𝖬𝖺𝗌𝗄𝐖𝑟\mathsf{Mask}(\mathbf{W},r) and 𝖬𝖺𝗌𝗄​(𝐛,r)𝖬𝖺𝗌𝗄𝐛𝑟\mathsf{Mask}(\mathbf{b},r) reduces the size by tensor product into ⌈|𝐯|⋅r⌉×|𝐰|⋅𝐯𝑟𝐰\lceil|\mathbf{v}|\cdot r\rceil\times|\mathbf{w}| and ⌈|𝐯|⋅r⌉⋅𝐯𝑟\lceil|\mathbf{v}|\cdot r\rceil, respectively. Hereafter, we consider two width configurations with the ratio r=0.5𝑟0.5r=0.5 and r=1.0𝑟1.0r=1.0 (i.e., 0.5x or 1.0x). At the t𝑡t-th iteration, the SNN model has the parameters θtksuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑘\theta_{t}^{k} with two width configurations: 0.5x width configuration θtk⊙Ξ1direct-productsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑘subscriptΞ1\theta_{t}^{k}\odot\Xi_{1} and 1.0x width configuration θtk⊙Ξ2direct-productsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑘subscriptΞ2\theta_{t}^{k}\odot\Xi_{2} (=θtkabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑘=\theta_{t}^{k}), where ⊙direct-product\odot is the element-wise product and ΞisubscriptΞ𝑖\Xi_{i} represents a binary mask for extracting the parameters of i𝑖i-th width configuration.

III-B Superposition SNN Training

Training a multi-width SNN is arduous. The SNN backpropagation (BP) is warped due to gradient interference of multi-width. For example, the BP of 0.5x width configurations interferences the BP of 1.0x’s and vice versa. This inter-width interference hinders not just inference accuracy but also training convergence. SlimTrain (see Algorithm 1), the first SNN training algorithm introduced in [21], partially ameliorates such inter-width interference by training alternative width configurations in descending order of size. While adhering to the sample principle, the authors of [20] have proposed a state-of-the-art SNN training technique called universal SNN (USTrain).

USTrain proposes the sandwich rule with the inplace knowledge distillation (IPKD), which are two notable techniques for training an SNN. To describe two notable techniques, the 1.01.01.0x model becomes a teacher guiding its sub-width models via knowledge distillation. By nature, it gives more benefits under a larger SNN (i.e., a better teacher) that has more sub-width configurations (i.e., more students). The IPKD encourages each sub-width (i.e., student) to provide a softmax output (i.e., logit) to that of the full-width (i.e., teacher), so that their overlapping BP gradients become less dissimilar, hence minimizing the inter-width interference. At its core, the inplace distillation and the sandwich rule are effective under the case where an SNN can be divided into more than two segments. The SNN architecture considered in this paper consists of only the LH and RH segments, making the USTrain unfit for our case. Moreover, during updating the local parameters of slimmable model, some of the parameters composing small model needs partial gradient calculation of big model.

While effective in standalone learning, in SlimFL with wireless connectivity, not all multi-width configurations are exchanged due to insufficient communication throughput. In other words, they exchanged width configurations are aggregated across devices, diluting the effectiveness of BN. In our experiments, we even observed training convergence failures due to BN. Furthermore, managing multiple BN layers not only consumes additional memory costs but also entails a high computing overhead.

To resolve this problem, we propose superpositioned USTrain (SUSTrain) algorithm. SUSTrain consists of two processes. First, all the forward propagation losses (FP) are holden. Then, all the width configurations are concurrently updated with the superpositioned gradients. With SUSTrain, a sub-width configuration (i.e., student) is trained using IPKD without the logit mismatch with its full-width configuration’s logit (i.e., teacher’s logit), while the full-width configuration is simultaneously trained using the ground truth.

In this paper, we consider that all devices have SNN with two-width configurations (i.e., one teacher and one student). Hereafter, we generalize the local SNN update rule for the device k𝑘k described as follows:

θt+1k=θtk−ηt​[w1​∇F^k​(θtk⊙Ξ1,ζtk)+w2​∇Fk​(θtk⊙Ξ2,ζtk)],subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑘𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑘subscript𝜂𝑡delimited-[]subscript𝑤1∇superscript^𝐹𝑘direct-productsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑘subscriptΞ1subscriptsuperscript𝜁𝑘𝑡subscript𝑤2∇superscript𝐹𝑘direct-productsubscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑘𝑡subscriptΞ2subscriptsuperscript𝜁𝑘𝑡\theta^{k}_{t+1}\!=\!\theta_{t}^{k}\!-\!\eta_{t}\big{[}w_{1}\nabla\hat{F}^{k}(\theta_{t}^{k}\odot\Xi_{1},\zeta^{k}_{t})\!+\!w_{2}\nabla{F}^{k}(\theta^{k}_{t}\odot\Xi_{2},\zeta^{k}_{t})\big{]}, (3)

where w1+w2=1subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤21w_{1}\!+\!w_{2}\!=\!1 and w1,w2>0subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤20w_{1},\!w_{2}\!>\!0. IV Global Model Aggregation with Superposition Coding & Successive Decoding

IV-A Superposition Coding & Successive Decoding

IV-A1 Wireless Systems

Consider a single base station equipped with a server. The server is associated with K𝐾K mobile devices at equal distance d𝑑d, e.g., uniformly distributed around a circle centered at the server with a radius of d𝑑d. Unless otherwise specified, hereafter we focus only on uplink communications. In the uplink, each device aims to upload S𝑆S messages corresponding to S𝑆S width configurations. For ease of explanation, we consider frequency division duplex (FDD) and orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM), which can be replaced with other duplexing and multiplexing schemes such as time division duplex (TDD) and time division multiplexing (TDM) [30] with minor modifications. For simplicity without loss of generality, we consider that the bandwidth is orthogonally and equally allocated to each device, thereby ignoring inter-user interference. Notwithstanding, we still consider the interference due to SC and SD operations. For mathematical amenability, we assume that the interference is treated as noise, and use the Shannon’s capacity formula with the Gaussian codebook, i.e., the use of optimal source and channel coding, which are widely used assumptions for analysis [28].

IV-A2 Superposition Coding (SC)

Recall that each mobile device k𝑘k stores a local model having S𝑆S width configurations. When S=2𝑆2S=2, the model is equally split as the LH and the RH segments, and the half-width model (0.5x) is the LH while the entire model (1.0x) is obtained by combining the LH and the RH. Generalizing this, we can treat S𝑆S width configurations as S𝑆S messages, and concurrently transmit them via SC [8]. To this end, consider that Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} transmit power is allocated to the i𝑖i-th message out of the total power budget P𝑃P, i.e., P=∑i=1SPi,∀i∈[1,S]formulae-sequence𝑃subscriptsuperscript𝑆𝑖1subscript𝑃𝑖for-all𝑖1𝑆P=\sum\limits^{S}_{i=1}\nolimits P_{i},\forall i\in[1,S]. Consider a mobile device k𝑘k transmitting a signal 𝐱ksubscript𝐱𝑘\mathbf{x}_{k} to the server over the same radio resource block, which is as:

𝐱k=∑i=1S𝐬k,i,subscript𝐱𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑆𝑖1subscript𝐬𝑘𝑖\mathbf{x}_{k}=\sum^{S}_{i=1}\nolimits\mathbf{s}_{k,i}, (4)

where 𝐬k,i∈𝒮ksubscript𝐬𝑘𝑖subscript𝒮𝑘\mathbf{s}_{k,i}\in\mathcal{S}_{k} denotes the symbol i𝑖i of mobile device k𝑘k, and 𝒮ksubscript𝒮𝑘\mathcal{S}_{k} is the Gaussian codebook for device k𝑘k, with 𝔼​[𝐬k,i]=0𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐬𝑘𝑖0\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{s}_{k,i}]=0 and 𝔼​[|𝐬k,i|2]=Pi𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐬𝑘𝑖2subscript𝑃𝑖\mathbb{E}[|\mathbf{s}_{k,i}|^{2}]=P_{i}, ∀i∈[1,S],∀k∈[1,K]formulae-sequencefor-all𝑖1𝑆for-all𝑘1𝐾\forall i\in[1,S],\forall k\in[1,K].

IV-A3 Decoding Success Probability and Successive Decoding (SD)

In SD, the receiver first decodes the strongest signal. Then, it sequentially decodes the next strongest signal, after cancelling out the decoded signal while treating the rest as interference, i.e., successive interference cancellation [31]. For simplicity, assume that Pi>Pi′subscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝑃superscript𝑖′P_{i}>P_{i^{\prime}} for all i′>isuperscript𝑖′𝑖i^{\prime}>i. Following SD, for the device k𝑘k, the server first decodes 𝐬k,1subscript𝐬𝑘1\mathbf{s}_{k,1} while treating the rest Pk,1Isuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘1𝐼P_{k,1}^{I} as interference, followed by decoding 𝐬k,2subscript𝐬𝑘2\mathbf{s}_{k,2} in the presence of the interference Pk,2I≤Pk,1Isuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘2𝐼superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘1𝐼P_{k,2}^{I}\leq P_{k,1}^{I}. Each decoding becomes successful when the throughput Rk,isubscript𝑅𝑘𝑖R_{k,i} at the server is no smaller than a pre-defined transmit rate u>0𝑢0u>0. The throughput is given by the Shannon’s capacity formula, yielding Rk,i=W​log2⁡(1+γk,i)subscript𝑅𝑘𝑖𝑊subscript21subscript𝛾𝑘𝑖R_{k,i}=W\log_{2}(1+\gamma_{k,i}) (bits/sec), where W𝑊W is the bandwidth, and γk,isubscript𝛾𝑘𝑖\gamma_{k,i} denotes the signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR).

Precisely, the received signal at the server, denoted by 𝐲ksubscript𝐲𝑘\mathbf{y}_{k}, is given by:

𝐲k=𝐡kH​𝐱k+𝐧k=𝐡kH​∑i=1S𝐬k,i+𝐧k,subscript𝐲𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑘𝐻subscript𝐱𝑘subscript𝐧𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑘𝐻subscriptsuperscript𝑆𝑖1subscript𝐬𝑘𝑖subscript𝐧𝑘\mathbf{y}_{k}=\mathbf{h}_{k}^{H}\mathbf{x}_{k}+\mathbf{n}_{k}=\mathbf{h}_{k}^{H}\sum^{S}_{i=1}\nolimits\mathbf{s}_{k,i}+\mathbf{n}_{k}, (5)

where 𝐡ksubscript𝐡𝑘\mathbf{h}_{k} is the channel coefficient, 𝐧k∼𝒞​𝒩​(0,σ𝐡2)similar-tosubscript𝐧𝑘𝒞𝒩0subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐡\mathbf{n}_{k}\sim\mathcal{CN}(0,\sigma^{2}_{\mathbf{h}}) represents the additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN), and (⋅)Hsuperscript⋅𝐻(\cdot)^{H} stands for the Hermitian transpose operator. According to SD, the SINR for the i𝑖i-th message sk,isubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖s_{k,i} is given by:

γk,i=|𝐡kH​𝐬k,i|2σ2+∑i′=i+1S|𝐡kH​𝐬k,i′|2,subscript𝛾𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐡𝐻𝑘subscript𝐬𝑘𝑖2superscript𝜎2subscriptsuperscript𝑆superscript𝑖′𝑖1superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐡𝐻𝑘subscript𝐬𝑘superscript𝑖′2\gamma_{k,i}=\frac{|\mathbf{h}^{H}_{k}\mathbf{s}_{k,i}|^{2}}{\sigma^{2}+\sum^{S}_{i^{\prime}=i+1}|\mathbf{h}^{H}_{k}\mathbf{s}_{k,i^{\prime}}|^{2}}, (6)

where σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} denotes the noise power. For ease of notation, the SINR in (6) is recast as:

γk,i=χk⋅d−β⋅Pi/(σ2+Pk,iI),subscript𝛾𝑘𝑖⋅subscript𝜒𝑘superscript𝑑𝛽subscript𝑃𝑖superscript𝜎2subscriptsuperscript𝑃𝐼𝑘𝑖\gamma_{k,i}=\chi_{k}\cdot d^{-\beta}\cdot P_{i}/(\sigma^{2}+P^{I}_{k,i}), (7)

in which 𝔼​[|𝐡k|2]=d−β𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑘2superscript𝑑𝛽\mathbb{E}[|\mathbf{h}_{k}|^{2}]=d^{-\beta} and χk∼Exp​(1)similar-tosubscript𝜒𝑘Exp1\chi_{k}\sim\textsf{Exp}(1) follow from the large-scale fading and Rayleigh small-scale fading, respectively. The term Pk,iI=χk​d−β​P^iIsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑖𝐼subscript𝜒𝑘superscript𝑑𝛽superscriptsubscript^𝑃𝑖𝐼P_{k,i}^{I}=\chi_{k}d^{-\beta}\hat{P}_{i}^{I} is the interference, where P^iI≜∑i′=i+1SPi′≜superscriptsubscript^𝑃𝑖𝐼subscriptsuperscript𝑆superscript𝑖′𝑖1subscript𝑃superscript𝑖′\hat{P}_{i}^{I}\triangleq\sum^{S}_{i^{\prime}=i+1}P_{i^{\prime}} for i≤S−1𝑖𝑆1i\leq S-1, and P^SI=Pk,SI=0subscriptsuperscript^𝑃𝐼𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝑃𝐼𝑘𝑆0\hat{P}^{I}_{S}=P^{I}_{k,S}=0 as there is no interference for the last message.

In SD, the decoding success of the i𝑖i-th message implies that not only the i𝑖i-th but also its all subsequent decoding successes; in other words, Rk,1>u,Rk,2>u,…​Rk,i>uformulae-sequencesubscript𝑅𝑘1𝑢formulae-sequencesubscript𝑅𝑘2𝑢…subscript𝑅𝑘𝑖𝑢R_{k,1}>u,R_{k,2}>u,...R_{k,i}>u or equivalently max⁡{Rk,1,Rk,2,…​Rk,i}>usubscript𝑅𝑘1subscript𝑅𝑘2…subscript𝑅𝑘𝑖𝑢\max\{R_{k,1},R_{k,2},...R_{k,i}\}>u. Recall that S𝑆S messages encoded as 𝐱ksubscript𝐱𝑘\mathbf{x}_{k} experience the same channel. Then, the decoding success probability pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} of the i𝑖i-th message is given as follows:

pisubscript𝑝𝑖\displaystyle p_{i} =Pr⁡(χk≥max⁡{cP1/u′−P^1I,⋯,cPi/u′−P^iI})absentprobabilitysubscript𝜒𝑘𝑐subscript𝑃1superscript𝑢′subscriptsuperscript^𝑃𝐼1⋯𝑐subscript𝑃𝑖superscript𝑢′subscriptsuperscript^𝑃𝐼𝑖\displaystyle=\Pr\!\left(\chi_{k}\!\geq\!\max\!\left\{\!\frac{c}{P_{1}/u^{\prime}-\hat{P}^{I}_{1}},\cdots\!,\frac{c}{P_{i}/u^{\prime}-\hat{P}^{I}_{i}}\!\right\}\!\right)\! (8)
=exp⁡(−max⁡{cP1/u′−P^1I,⋯,cPi/u′−P^iI}),absent𝑐subscript𝑃1superscript𝑢′subscriptsuperscript^𝑃𝐼1⋯𝑐subscript𝑃𝑖superscript𝑢′subscriptsuperscript^𝑃𝐼𝑖\displaystyle=\exp\!\left(-\max\!\left\{\!\frac{c}{P_{1}/u^{\prime}-\hat{P}^{I}_{1}},\cdots\!,\frac{c}{P_{i}/u^{\prime}-\hat{P}^{I}_{i}}\!\right\}\!\right)\!, (9)

where c=σ2​dβ𝑐superscript𝜎2superscript𝑑𝛽c=\sigma^{2}d^{\beta}, u′=2uW−1superscript𝑢′superscript2𝑢𝑊1u^{\prime}=2^{\frac{u}{W}}-1, and the last step follows from the complementary cumulative distribution function (CCDF) of χksubscript𝜒𝑘\chi_{k}.

IV-B SlimFL Operations

We discuss SlimFL and global model aggregation in further detail. SlimFL is denoted by the symbols shown in Table I. Algorithm 4 describes the fundamental SlimFL operations. The network consists of K𝐾K devices that are linked through wireless connections to a parameter server. Each device uses SC whilst communicating with the server, whereas the server uses SD. To be more descriptive, k𝑘k-th device has a local dataset Zk∈𝒁superscript𝑍𝑘𝒁Z^{k}\in\bm{Z} and an SNN parameter θksuperscript𝜃𝑘\theta^{k} with two width configurations. Across devices, the global data 𝒁𝒁\bm{Z} may be IID or non-IID. Each SNN θksuperscript𝜃𝑘\theta^{k} is subdivided into an LH θk⊙Ξdirect-productsuperscript𝜃𝑘Ξ\theta^{k}\odot\Xi and a RH segment θk⊙Ξ−1direct-productsuperscript𝜃𝑘superscriptΞ1\theta^{k}\odot\Xi^{-1}, where Ξ=Ξ1ΞsubscriptΞ1\Xi=\Xi_{1} and Ξ−1=Ξ2−Ξ1superscriptΞ1subscriptΞ2subscriptΞ1\Xi^{-1}=\Xi_{2}-\Xi_{1}. Superposition training is used to train the k𝑘k-th local device (lines 4–9), which is expressed as (3). The local device transmits to the server the SC-encoded local model θksuperscript𝜃𝑘\theta^{k}. Each local device transmits two messages (i.e., LH and RH segments), each with a distinct transmission power P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} and P2subscript𝑃2P_{2} relative to P1≫P2much-greater-thansubscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2P_{1}\gg P_{2}. The uniform random variable ρ∈[0,1]𝜌01\rho\in[0,1] is sampled for user k𝑘k as ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k}. The sampled ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k} and the decoding success probability p1subscript𝑝1p_{1}, p2subscript𝑝2p_{2} are used as a criterion for whether LH and RH are successfully decoded. It is identical to calculate (9). In accordance with (9), after reception, the server can successively decode using SD and obtain: (i) a 0.5x model if χ≥c/(P1/u′−P2)𝜒𝑐subscript𝑃1superscript𝑢′subscript𝑃2\chi\geq c/(P_{1}/u^{\prime}-P_{2}) (lines 15–17) is satisfied; (ii) 1.01.01.0x model if the channel fading gain satisfies χ≥max⁡{c/(P1/u′−P2),c/(P2/u′)}𝜒𝑐subscript𝑃1superscript𝑢′subscript𝑃2𝑐subscript𝑃2superscript𝑢′\chi\geq\max\{c/(P_{1}/u^{\prime}-P_{2}),c/(P_{2}/u^{\prime})\} (lines 18–20); and (iii) otherwise it obtains no model. As a result, the RH segments from 𝖥𝖥\mathsf{F} of devices and the LH segments from 𝖧∪𝖥𝖧𝖥\mathsf{H}\cup\mathsf{F} of devices are combined by the server.

V SlimFL Convergence Analysis

V-A Assumptions

In order to analyze the convergence rate of SlimFL, the following assumptions are considered.

  1. 1.

    Regardless of SC or SD, downlink decoding is always successful (Algorithm 4, lines 29–32). The fact that the server (e.g., a base station) has a far higher broadcast power than the uplink power contributes to this.

  2. 2.

    We assume that K𝐾K is big enough that |𝖧∪𝖥|≈K​p1𝖧𝖥𝐾subscript𝑝1|\mathsf{H}\cup\mathsf{F}|\approx Kp_{1} and |𝖥|≈K​p2𝖥𝐾subscript𝑝2|\mathsf{F}|\approx Kp_{2}, where p1subscript𝑝1p_{1} and p2subscript𝑝2p_{2} are the LH and RH segment decoding success probability, respectively, provided in (9). As a result, during the t𝑡t-th communication cycle, the server builds the following global model θtGsubscriptsuperscript𝜃𝐺𝑡\theta^{G}_{t}:

    θtG←1K​p1​∑k∈𝖧∪𝖥θtk⊙Ξ+1K​p2​∑k∈𝖥θtk⊙Ξ−1.←subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝐺𝑡1𝐾subscript𝑝1subscript𝑘𝖧𝖥direct-productsubscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑘𝑡Ξ1𝐾subscript𝑝2subscript𝑘𝖥direct-productsubscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑘𝑡superscriptΞ1\theta^{G}_{t}\leftarrow\frac{1}{Kp_{1}}\sum_{k\in\mathsf{H}\cup\mathsf{F}}\nolimits\theta^{k}_{t}\odot\Xi+\frac{1}{Kp_{2}}\sum_{k\in\mathsf{F}}\nolimits\theta^{k}_{t}\odot\Xi^{-1}. (10)
  3. 3.

    One communication round is assumed per local iteration or mathematically tractability. According to [32], FedAvg does not guarantee that a number of local iterations is proportional to the performance. Since the number of local iterations at each communication round is 111, superscript G𝐺G is omitted, resulting in θt=θtGsubscript𝜃𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝐺\theta_{t}=\theta_{t}^{G}. This assumption will be further discussed in Sec VI-E3.

Based on these assumptions, the convergence analysis of SlimFL is mathematically tractable as discussed in Sec. V-B.

V-B Convergence Analysis

This paper analyzes the convergence of SlimFL in non-IID data distribution. We follow the fundamental derivation techniques utilized [33, 34] for FedAvg. One significant challenge in the convergence analysis for SlimFL is due to the local model updates in (3) and the global model aggregation in (10) include sophisticated binary masks owing to the SNN architecture as well as SC and SD. As a result, unlike FedAvg, whose global objective function is the weighted average of local loss functions {Fk​(θtk)}superscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑘\{F^{k}(\theta_{t}^{k})\}, i.e., empirical risk, SlimFL’s objective function F​(θt)𝐹subscript𝜃𝑡F(\theta_{t}) is unknown. Alternatively, we define F​(θt)𝐹subscript𝜃𝑡F(\theta_{t}) in terms of its gradient ft=∇F​(θt)subscript𝑓𝑡∇𝐹subscript𝜃𝑡f_{t}=\nabla F(\theta_{t}), which can be obtained using SlimFL’s local and global operations, as discussed below. After a downlink, the device k𝑘k replaces its local model with the downloaded global model, represented by θtk←θt←subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑘𝑡subscript𝜃𝑡\theta^{k}_{t}\leftarrow\theta_{t}. The device then changes the local model as:

θt+1k←θt−ηt​gtk,←subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑘𝑡1subscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑔𝑘𝑡\theta^{k}_{t+1}\leftarrow\theta_{t}-\eta_{t}g^{k}_{t}, (11)

where gtk=∑i=12wi​∇Fk​(θt⊙Ξi,ζtk)subscriptsuperscript𝑔𝑘𝑡subscriptsuperscript2𝑖1subscript𝑤𝑖∇superscript𝐹𝑘direct-productsubscript𝜃𝑡subscriptΞ𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝜁𝑘𝑡g^{k}_{t}=\sum^{2}_{i=1}w_{i}\nabla F^{k}(\theta_{t}\odot\Xi_{i},\zeta^{k}_{t}) follows from (3). We assume that the student’s soft goal may be approximated by the student’s hard objective, i.e.,

F^k​(θt⊙Ξi,ζtk)≈Fk​(θt⊙Ξi,ζtk).superscript^𝐹𝑘direct-productsubscript𝜃𝑡subscriptΞ𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝜁𝑘𝑡superscript𝐹𝑘direct-productsubscript𝜃𝑡subscriptΞ𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝜁𝑘𝑡\hat{F}^{k}(\theta_{t}\odot\Xi_{i},\zeta^{k}_{t})\approx F^{k}(\theta_{t}\odot\Xi_{i},\zeta^{k}_{t}). (12)

Next, after the uplink, the server aggregates the updated local models to form the global model θt+1subscript𝜃𝑡1\theta_{t+1}. By applying (11) to (10), the resulting global model is as follows:

=θt−ηt​(1K​p1​∑k∈𝖧∪𝖥gtk⊙Ξ+1K​p2​∑k∈𝖥gtk⊙Ξ−1⏟:=ft),absentsubscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡subscript⏟1𝐾subscript𝑝1subscript𝑘𝖧𝖥direct-productsubscriptsuperscript𝑔𝑘𝑡Ξ1𝐾subscript𝑝2subscript𝑘𝖥direct-productsubscriptsuperscript𝑔𝑘𝑡superscriptΞ1assignabsentsubscript𝑓𝑡\displaystyle=\theta_{t}-\eta_{t}\Big{(}\underbrace{\frac{1}{Kp_{1}}\sum_{k\in\mathsf{H}\cup\mathsf{F}}g^{k}_{t}\odot\Xi+\frac{1}{Kp_{2}}\sum_{k\in\mathsf{F}}g^{k}_{t}\odot\Xi^{-1}}_{:=f_{t}}\Big{)}, (13)

resulting in ftsubscript𝑓𝑡f_{t} in (13), which characterizes F​(θt)𝐹subscript𝜃𝑡F(\theta_{t}). In (13), the last step can be obtained from |𝖧∪𝖥|=K​p1𝖧𝖥𝐾subscript𝑝1|\mathsf{H}\cup\mathsf{F}|=Kp_{1}, |𝖥|=K​p2𝖥𝐾subscript𝑝2|\mathsf{F}|=Kp_{2}, and θt=θt⊙(Ξ+Ξ−1)subscript𝜃𝑡direct-productsubscript𝜃𝑡ΞsuperscriptΞ1\theta_{t}=\theta_{t}\odot(\Xi+\Xi^{-1}).

Hereafter we use the bar notation ⋅¯¯⋅\bar{\cdot} for the value averaged over {ζtk}superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑡𝑘\{\zeta_{t}^{k}\}, and ∗ for indicating the optimum. For the functions F𝐹F and {Fk}superscript𝐹𝑘\{F^{k}\}, we analyze the following commonly used assumptions to prove convergence of FedAvg under non-IID data distributions [33, 35]. According to [36], following assumptions are justifiable in SNN architectures.

Assumption 1.

(L-smoothness) FFF and {Fk}superscriptFk\{F^{k}\} are LLL-smooth, i.e.,

Fk​(θv)≤Fk​(θw)+(θv−θw)T​∇Fk​(θw)+L2​‖θv−θw‖2superscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝜃𝑣superscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝜃𝑤superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑣subscript𝜃𝑤𝑇∇superscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝜃𝑤𝐿2superscriptnormsubscript𝜃𝑣subscript𝜃𝑤2F^{k}(\theta_{v})\leq F^{k}(\theta_{w})+(\theta_{v}-\theta_{w})^{T}\nabla F^{k}(\theta_{w})+\frac{L}{2}\|\theta_{v}-\theta_{w}\|^{2} (14)

for all v,w>0𝑣𝑤0v,w>0.

Assumption 2.

(𝝁𝝁\bm{\mu}-strong convexity) FFF and {Fk}superscriptFk\{F^{k}\} are μμ\mu-strong convex: i.e.,

Fk​(θv)≥Fk​(θw)+(θv−θw)T​∇Fk​(θw)+μ2​‖θv−θw‖2superscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝜃𝑣superscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝜃𝑤superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑣subscript𝜃𝑤𝑇∇superscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝜃𝑤𝜇2superscriptnormsubscript𝜃𝑣subscript𝜃𝑤2F^{k}(\theta_{v})\geq F^{k}(\theta_{w})+(\theta_{v}-\theta_{w})^{T}\nabla F^{k}(\theta_{w})+\frac{\mu}{2}\|\theta_{v}-\theta_{w}\|^{2} (15)

for all v,w>0𝑣𝑤0v,w>0.

Since linear sum preserves strong convexity and smoothness, F~ksuperscript~𝐹𝑘\tilde{F}^{k} also has the μ𝜇\mu-strong convexity and L𝐿L-smoothness. In addition, we also assume our global model has same properties.

Assumption 3.

(Bounded local gradient variance) The variance of the local gradient ∇Fk​(θk,ζtk)∇superscriptFksuperscriptθksubscriptsuperscriptζkt\nabla F^{k}(\theta^{k},\zeta^{k}_{t}) is bounded within ZksubscriptZkZ_{k}, which is given as

𝔼​[‖∇Fk​(θk,ζtk)−∇F¯k​(θ)‖2]≤σk2.𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇superscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝜃𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜁𝑘𝑡∇superscript¯𝐹𝑘𝜃2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla F^{k}(\theta^{k},\zeta^{k}_{t})-\nabla\bar{F}^{k}(\theta)\|^{2}]\leq\sigma_{k}^{2}. (16)

Inspired by [34], we define a factor that measures the non-IIDness of 𝒁𝒁\bm{Z} as:

δ=1K​∑k=1Kσk2.𝛿1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2\delta=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\nolimits\sigma_{k}^{2}. (17)

Indeed, the variance (over k𝑘k) of the local gradient variance (over Zksubscript𝑍𝑘Z_{k}) is defined as:

σ¯≜1K​∑k=1K(σk−1K​∑k=1Kσk)2.≜¯𝜎1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜎𝑘2\bar{\sigma}\triangleq\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\nolimits\left(\sigma_{k}-\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\nolimits\sigma_{k}\right)^{2}. (18)

This characterizes the data distributions over devices, and so does δ𝛿\delta without loss of generality.

To prove the convergence of SlimFL, we derive the following two lemmas as referred to Appendix A-A, A-B.

Lemma 1.

(Bounded global gradient variance) Under Assumption 3, the variance of the global gradient ftsubscriptftf_{t} is bounded within 𝐙𝐙\bm{Z}, which is given as

𝔼​‖ft−f¯t‖2≤B𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝑓𝑡subscript¯𝑓𝑡2𝐵{\mathbb{E}}\|{f}_{t}-\bar{f}_{t}\|^{2}\leq B (19)

where B=4​δ​(1p1+1p2)​∑i=12wi2𝐵4𝛿1subscript𝑝11subscript𝑝2subscriptsuperscript2𝑖1subscriptsuperscript𝑤2𝑖B=4\delta(\frac{1}{p_{1}}+\frac{1}{p_{2}})\sum^{2}_{i=1}w^{2}_{i}.

Lemma 2.

(Per-round global model progress) Under Assumptions 1 and 2 with a learning rate ηt≤1Lsubscriptηt1L\eta_{t}\leq\frac{1}{L} , the error between the updated global model and its optimum progress as

𝔼​‖θt+1−θ∗‖2≤(1−μ​ηt2)​𝔼​‖θt−θ∗‖2+ηt2​B𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝜃𝑡1superscript𝜃21𝜇subscript𝜂𝑡2𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝜃𝑡superscript𝜃2subscriptsuperscript𝜂2𝑡𝐵{\mathbb{E}}\|\theta_{t+1}-\theta^{*}\|^{2}\leq(1-\frac{\mu\eta_{t}}{2}){\mathbb{E}}\|\theta_{t}-\theta^{*}\|^{2}+\eta^{2}_{t}B (20)

By Lemma 1 and Lemma 2, the convergence of SlimFL is proved. The full derivation of this proof is in Appendix A-C.

Theorem 1.

(SlimFL Convergence) Under Assumptions 1–3 with the learning rate ηt=2μ​t+2​L−μsubscript𝜂𝑡2𝜇𝑡2𝐿𝜇\eta_{t}=\frac{2}{\mu{t}+2L-\mu}, one has

where B=4​δ​(1p1+1p2)​∑i=12wi2𝐵4𝛿1subscript𝑝11subscript𝑝2subscriptsuperscript2𝑖1subscriptsuperscript𝑤2𝑖B=4\delta(\frac{1}{p_{1}}+\frac{1}{p_{2}})\sum^{2}_{i=1}w^{2}_{i} and Δt≜𝔼​‖θt−θ∗‖2≜subscriptΔ𝑡𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝜃𝑡superscript𝜃2\Delta_{t}\triangleq{\mathbb{E}}\|\theta_{t}-\theta^{*}\|^{2}. Therefore, 𝔼​[F​(θt)]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝜃𝑡{\mathbb{E}}[F(\theta_{t})] converges to F∗superscript𝐹F^{*} as t→∞→𝑡t\rightarrow\infty.

V-C Several Insights of Convergence Analysis

The result of Theorem 1 exhibits several insights into SlimFL.

V-C1 Failure under extremely poor channels

Consider a channel with very poor quality, where the server is unable to decode 1.0x models and hence collects only 0.5x models (i.e., p2≈0subscript𝑝20p_{2}\approx 0 and p1>0subscript𝑝10p_{1}>0). In this case, despite the optimality gap aggregating 0.5x models, the term B𝐵B diverges. In these channel conditions, SC becomes inefficient, and vanilla FL with 0.5x models is preferred to SlimFL.

V-C2 Robustness to poor channels

In (21), we confirm that an increasing number of 0.5x and 1.0x models aggregated (i.e., increasing p1subscript𝑝1p_{1} and p2subscript𝑝2p_{2}) helps equally to reach the global optimal bound. As a result, aggregating 0.5x models can further alleviate 1.0x models’ frequent decoding failures on poor channels.

V-C3 Robustness to non-IID data

The optimality gap widens as δ𝛿\delta (i.e., more non-IID). Contrary to vanilla FL, which benefits primarily from aggregating either 0.5x or 1.0x models, SlimFL’s increased gap may be mitigated by aggregating not just 1.0x but also 0.5x models. Hence, we conclude that SlimFL is superior for non-IID data distributions and moderately poor channel conditions where 0≪p1,p2<1formulae-sequencemuch-less-than0subscript𝑝1subscript𝑝210\ll p_{1},p_{2}<1. Vanilla FL with just 1.0x models or 0.5x models is recommended for highly excellent (i.e., p2≈1subscript𝑝21p_{2}\approx 1) or extremely bad (i.e., p1≈0subscript𝑝10p_{1}\approx 0) channel conditions, respectively. SlimFL’s favorable conditions and efficacy will be validated by simulation in Sec. VI.

V-C4 Design principle of SlimFL

Additionally, Theorem 1 gives design principles for SC and ST as detailed in the following two propositions.

Proposition 1 (Optimal SC power allocations).

Consider the SC power allocation ratio λ∈(0.5,1]𝜆0.51\lambda\in(0.5,1] such that P1=λ​Psubscript𝑃1𝜆𝑃P_{1}=\lambda P and P2=(1−λ)​Psubscript𝑃21𝜆𝑃P_{2}=(1-\lambda)P. If λ≫max⁡{0.5,c​u′​(1+u′)/P}much-greater-than𝜆0.5𝑐superscript𝑢′1superscript𝑢′𝑃\lambda\gg\max\left\{0.5,{cu^{\prime}(1+u^{\prime})}/{P}\right\}, the optimal SC power allocation ratio that minimizes the RHS of (21) is given as

λ∗=u′+1+u′−1u′.superscript𝜆superscript𝑢′1superscript𝑢′1superscript𝑢′\lambda^{*}=\frac{u^{\prime}+\sqrt{1+u^{\prime}}-1}{u^{\prime}}. (22)
Proof.

Define D≜1p1+1p2≜𝐷1subscript𝑝11subscript𝑝2D\triangleq\frac{1}{p_{1}}+\frac{1}{p_{2}}. According to the RHS of (21), λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*} minimize D𝐷D. Since P1>P2subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2P_{1}>P_{2}, we have

D=exp⁡(−cλ​P/u′−(1−λ)​P)+exp⁡(−c(1−λ)​P/u′).𝐷𝑐𝜆𝑃superscript𝑢′1𝜆𝑃𝑐1𝜆𝑃superscript𝑢′D=\exp\left(-\frac{c}{\lambda P/u^{\prime}-(1-\lambda)P}\right)+\exp\left(-\frac{c}{(1-\lambda)P/u^{\prime}}\right). (23)

If λ≫c​u′​(1+u′)/Pmuch-greater-than𝜆𝑐superscript𝑢′1superscript𝑢′𝑃\lambda\gg cu^{\prime}(1+u^{\prime})/{P}, we can approximate both terms in D𝐷D using the first-order Taylor expansion, yielding

D≈2+cλ​P/u′−(1−λ)​P+c(1−λ)​P/u′.𝐷2𝑐𝜆𝑃superscript𝑢′1𝜆𝑃𝑐1𝜆𝑃superscript𝑢′D\approx 2+\frac{c}{\lambda P/u^{\prime}-(1-\lambda)P}+\frac{c}{(1-\lambda)P/u^{\prime}}. (24)

The approximated D𝐷D is convex, and the first-order necessary condition gives the optimum. ∎

Note that the condition λ≫max⁡{0.5,c​u′​(1+u′)/P}much-greater-than𝜆0.5𝑐superscript𝑢′1superscript𝑢′𝑃\lambda\gg\max\left\{0.5,{cu^{\prime}(1+u^{\prime})}/{P}\right\} can be satisfied under sufficiently small model sizes (e.g., t′→0→superscript𝑡′0t^{\prime}\rightarrow 0), wide bandwidth (e.g., W→∞→𝑊W\rightarrow\infty), good channel conditions (e.g., σ2→0→superscript𝜎20\sigma^{2}\rightarrow 0), and/or a large total transmit power budget (e.g., P→∞→𝑃P\rightarrow\infty).

Proposition 2 (Optimal ST ratio).

The optimal ST ratio that minimize the RHS of (21) are given as w1∗=w2∗=1/2superscriptsubscript𝑤1superscriptsubscript𝑤212w_{1}^{*}=w_{2}^{*}=1/2.

Proof.

The RHS of (21) is minimized at the minimum of ∑i=12wi2superscriptsubscript𝑖12superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖2\sum_{i=1}^{2}w_{i}^{2}. By the C-S inequality, we have

∑i=12wi2≥12​(∑i=12wi)2.subscriptsuperscript2𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖212superscriptsubscriptsuperscript2𝑖1subscript𝑤𝑖2\sum^{2}_{i=1}w_{i}^{2}\geq\frac{1}{2}\left(\sum^{2}_{i=1}w_{i}\right)^{2}. (25)

The desirable result is obtained by combining the condition ∑i=12wi=1subscriptsuperscript2𝑖1subscript𝑤𝑖1\sum^{2}_{i=1}w_{i}=1 in (3) with the equality condition of the AM-GM inequality. The influence of λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*} and wi∗superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i}^{*} will be demonstrated by simulation in the next section.

∎

VI Experiments

We investigate the effectiveness and feasibility of SlimFL corresponding to the numerical results of convergence analysis, the robustness to various channel conditions and non-IID data distributions, and computation/communication efficiency.

VI-A Simulation Settings

To show the effectiveness of the proposed SlimFL, we consider a classification task with the Fashion MNIST (FMNIST) image dataset [37]. The impact of other datasets such as the CIFAR-10 and MNIST datasets will be discussed in VI-E. The dataset is randomly sharded and distributed across devices. Following [38], the non-IIDness of the data distribution is modeled using a Dirichlet distribution with its concentration parameter α∈{0.1,1.0,10}𝛼0.11.010\alpha\in\{0.1,1.0,10\}, where the higher α𝛼\alpha implies the more non-IID data distribution as illustrated in Fig 2. For numerical experiments, we adopt the light model of slimmable MobileNet, i.e., UL-MobileNet111This paper utilizes Ultra-Light MobileNet (UL-MobileNet) under the consideration of the limited computing capacity of local.It follows MobileNet architecture [39]. UL-MobileNet consists of five convolution layers activated by the ReLU6 function, average pooling function, and linear layer.. We consider a single communication round consisting of a pair of uplink and downlink transmissions for each local training iteration. The communication channels over different devices are orthogonal in both uplink and downlink. The Rayleigh fading gain χ𝜒\chi for each channel realization follows an exponential distribution χ∼Exp​(1)similar-to𝜒Exp1\chi\sim\textsf{Exp}(1) [28]. The corresponding communication and neural network hyperparameters are summarized in Table II. We adopt Vanilla FL as a comparison technique. Vanilla FL is widely used FL technique (i.e., FedAvg) with a fixed-width SNN model without leveraging SC nor SD. We consider three Vanilla FL schemes as listed follows:

  1. 1.

    Vanilla-FL 0.50.50.5x/1.01.01.0x: Vanilla FL 0.50.50.5x and 1.01.01.0x use only 0.50.50.5x- or 1.01.01.0x-width configurations, respectively. We compare model accuracy and the convergence of SlimFL with Vanilla FL-0.50.50.5x and 1.01.01.0x corresponding to the robustness to various channel conditions and non-IIDness in Sec. VI-B.

  2. 2.

    Vanilla-FL 1.51.51.5x: Due to the lack of width-adjustable SNNs, each device in Vanilla FL-1.51.51.5x separately runs fixed-width 0.50.50.5x and 1.01.01.0x models. Then, devices can choose the 0.50.50.5x or 1.01.01.0x model considering energy heterogeneity, which SlimFL can. In other words, Vanilla FL-1.51.51.5x operates the two FedAvg operations separately for 0.50.50.5x and 1.01.01.0x models by doubling the bandwidth, transmission power, and computing resources. By comparing SlimFL to Vanilla FL-1.51.51.5x, we investigate the difference of accuracy, received bits and energy cost.

VI-B Efficiency, Robustness, and Scalability of SlimFL

We carry out to analyze SlimFL’s performance to Vanilla FL in situations with a variety of communication conditions and non-IID settings. To assess the efficiency of communication and computation, we first calculate computation cost for UL-MobileNet feed-forwarding [40] and communication cost per one communication round.

VI-B1 Communication Efficiency

Between ten devices and a server, the total quantity of data communicated is 205.8205.8205.8MBytes for SlimFL and Vanilla FL-1.0x, and 102.9102.9102.9MBytes for Vanilla FL-0.5x under ideal channel conditions (i.e., always successful decoding). We investigate the efficiency of communication resources in both good and bad channel conditions to validate the effectiveness of SC and SD. The experimental result for this subsection is presented in Table V, which shows that SlimFL delivers up to 3.52%percent3.523.52\% fewer dropped bits than Vanilla FL-1.0x when SC and SD are being used. SlimFL enjoys the benefits mentioned above while consuming only half of the transmission power and bandwidth compared to Vanilla FL-1.5x, as presented in Table V, corroborating its communication efficiency. Because a part of the transmission power of SlimFL is allocated to 0.5x models, SlimFL decodes less than 1.0x model bits than Vanilla FL-1.0x. In return, SlimFL receives not only 1.0x models but also 0.5x models simultaneously. The additional received 0.5x models coincide with the LH parts of the 1.0x models, which improve the accuracy and convergence speed of both 0.5x and 1.0x models.

VI-B2 Energy Efficiency

Thus far, we have evaluated SlimFL’s performance after training using 1,00010001,000 epochs. We estimate the energy consumption till convergence in this section. Numerical convergence in training is defined as the point at which the standard deviation (std) of test accuracy falls below a predefined threshold and the lowest test accuracy exceeds the average test accuracy in 100100100 consecutive rounds. To assess model convergence, we establish the reference values for the mean μ𝖱𝖾𝖿subscript𝜇𝖱𝖾𝖿\mu_{\mathsf{Ref}} as 80%percent8080\% and σ𝖱𝖾𝖿subscript𝜎𝖱𝖾𝖿\sigma_{\mathsf{Ref}} as 7.25%percent7.257.25\%, respectively. Convergence occurs when the average Top-1 accuracy for 100100100 consecutive epochs is greater than μ𝖱𝖾𝖿subscript𝜇𝖱𝖾𝖿\mu_{\mathsf{Ref}} and the average std is less than σ𝖱𝖾𝖿subscript𝜎𝖱𝖾𝖿\sigma_{\mathsf{Ref}}. With this convergence criterion, Table VI compares the overall energy costs of SlimFL and Vanilla FL-1.5x until convergence, based on the communication and processing energy costs per round in Table IV. As shown in Table VI, harsh non-IIDness (α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1) with poor channel conditions makes FL convergence hard. SlimFL, on average, produces a 3.63.63.6x reduction in total computing costs and a 2.92.92.9x reduction in total communication costs until their convergences. In addition, Fig. 3 shows the energy efficiency results corresponding to accuracy. As shown in Fig. 3(a), SlimFL requires only the 32.63%percent32.6332.63\% of Vanilla FL-1.5x’s total communication cost for model convergence. Similarly, the computing cost for SlimFL is the 44.37%percent44.3744.37\% of Vanilla FL-1.5x’s as shown in Fig. 3(b). This increased energy efficiency is according to SlimFL’s faster convergence even in non-IID and/or bad channel circumstances caused by SC and SD.

VI-B3 Robustness to Poor Channels

SlimFL and Vanilla FL both achieve high accuracy when channel conditions are good, as shown in Fig. 5 and Table VII. When the channel condition deteriorates from good to poor, however, as shown in Fig. 5(c,f) and Table VII, Vanilla FL1.0x’s maximum accuracy at α=10𝛼10\alpha=10 declines from 868686 to 828282 percent. SlimFL-1.0x, on the other hand, retains its maximum accuracy of 878787 percent at α=10𝛼10\alpha=10 in both good and bad channel conditions. Additionally, at α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1, SlimFL-1.0x outperforms Vanilla FL-1.0x by 18%percent1818\% in terms of top-1 accuracy, despite the fact that Vanilla FL-1.0x consumes more communication and computing resources. Additionally, as the channel condition degrades, the std of Vanilla FL-1.0x’s top-1 accuracy increases by up to 59%percent5959\%, while SlimFL’s std increases by just 31%percent3131\%. These findings show SlimFL’s resistance to poor channels conditions, as well as its resistance to non-IID data distributions (low α𝛼\alpha) and communication efficiency.

VI-B4 Robustness to Non-IID Data

SlimFL-0.5x has a stable convergence under α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1 condition, as indicated in Fig. 5(d–f) and Table VII In poor channel conditions and with the non-IID distribution (α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1), Vanilla FL-0.5x and Vanilla FL-1.0x display the std of 8.38.38.3 and 9.29.29.2. On the other hand, SlimFL-0.5x and SlimFL-1.0x both demonstrate the std of 2.42.42.4 and 2.92.92.9 with top-1 accuracy. This propensity persists even when α=1𝛼1\alpha=1, α=10𝛼10\alpha=10 are prevalent. SlimFL-1.0x and SlimFL-0.5x have a smaller coefficient of variation than Vanilla FL-1.0x and Vanilla FL-0.5x. This accentuates SlimFL’s robustness to non-IID data on poor channels.

VI-B5 Scalability

As shown in Fig. 6, SlimFL’s accuracy increases as the number of federating devices increases. The SlimFL-0.5x achieves an accuracy of up to 79%, while the SlimFL-1.0x reaches an accuracy of up to 85%. Additionally, with non-IIDness (α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1) and 70 federating local devices, SlimFL-0.5x achieves a greater level of accuracy than SlimFL-1.0x with 20 federating local devices. Based on the experimental results, it is expected that when constructing a FL system using non-IID datasets, optimality can be obtained by adjusting the number of local devices and width through SlimFL adaption.

VI-C Ablation Studies on Optimization and Local Training

VI-C1 Effectiveness of SC Power Allocation Optimization

We present a method for optimizing our suggested model by modifying the ST parameter wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i}. The numerical results of optimal λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*} are shown in Fig. 7. The derivative of the Tayler expansion is used in Proposition 1 to compute λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*}. The ideal power allocation factor is λ∗=0.662superscript𝜆0.662\lambda^{*}=0.662, which is the same value as the numerical optimum, as determined by the analytical solution. The simulation was carried out using the baseline with λ=0.8𝜆0.8\lambda=0.8 in a non-IID settings (i.e., α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1) to verify the recommendation from Proposition 1. The experiment’s result is shown in Fig. 8(a). The top-1 accuracy with λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*} is 6.4%percent6.46.4\% higher than top-1 accuracy with 0.5x and 8.8%percent8.88.8\% higher than top-1 accuracy with 1.0x. To put it another way, Proposition 1 acts as a guiding principle in SlimFL.

VI-C2 Effectiveness of ST Ratio Optimization

When w1=⋯=wS=1Ssubscript𝑤1⋯subscript𝑤𝑆1𝑆w_{1}=\cdots=w_{S}=\frac{1}{S} in Proposition 2, SlimFL has a tight bound. Since S=2𝑆2S=2 is taken into account in our proposed scheme, all hyperparameters that make up ST should be 0.50.50.5, i.e., (w1∗,w2∗)=(0.5,0.5)subscriptsuperscript𝑤1subscriptsuperscript𝑤20.50.5(w^{*}_{1},w^{*}_{2})=(0.5,0.5). To verify Proposition 2, we construct a baseline with (w1,w2)=(0.3,0.7)subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤20.30.7(w_{1},w_{2})=(0.3,0.7). Fig. 8(b) depicts the performance with different wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i}. Under the optimal ST scheme, top-1 accuracy reaches 78 percent, whereas baseline accuracy is 69 percent. As a result, the ST guideline has a good impact on SlimFL’s performance.

VI-C3 Effectiveness of the Proposed Local Training Algorithm

To configure out the superiority of the proposed local training algorithm (i.e., SUSTrain), we compare SUSTrain with SlimTrain [21] and USTrain [20] which are not only well-known but also state-of-the-art SNN training algorithms. The two training algorithms are presented in Algorithm 1 and Algorithm 2). We investigate the performance between training algorithm in the scheme with ten local devices and σ2=−30superscript𝜎230\sigma^{2}=-30dB in two data distributions (i.e., α=0.1,1.0𝛼0.11.0\alpha=0.1,1.0). As shown by experiments in Fig. 9(a), USTrain is unfit for SlimFL with high non-IID condition (i.e., α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1), where SlimTrain even outperforms USTrain. With IID data distribution (i.e., α=1.0𝛼1.0\alpha=1.0), USTrain outperforms SlimTrain. Fig. 9 corroborates that regardless of the data distributions, SUSTrain achieves high accuracy with fast convergence, as opposed to USTrain which is effective only under IID data distributions (i.e., α=1.0𝛼1.0\alpha=1.0). We conjecture that the problem comes from the use of outdated teacher’s knowledge in USTrain. In USTrain, the teacher’s logit is set as the value before updating the teacher’s model and is compared with a student after updating the teacher’s model. Non-IID data distributions exacerbate this mismatch, where the full-width teacher model is significantly updated in the first epoch after downloading the global model due to the huge gap between local and global models.

VI-D Impact on Heterogeneous Energy Capacity

To verify the impact on heterogeneous computing capacities of devices, we investigate six-width configurations (e.g., 1/6x, 2/6x, ⋯⋯\cdots, and 6/6x). First, we train SNNs with the default settings of SlimFL (α=10𝛼10\alpha=10, K=10𝐾10K=10, σ2=−30​dBsuperscript𝜎230dB\sigma^{2}=-30\text{dB}). Then, we measure top-1 accuracy and calculate FLOPS. Its specification is presented in Table VIII. Second, we investigate the dynamic width adaptation to the device, which has a time-varying theoretical peak performance of the CPU, denoted as RpeaksubscriptRpeak\textsf{R}_{\textsf{peak}} (MFLOPS). We set Rpeak∈[20,230]subscriptRpeak20230\textsf{R}_{\textsf{peak}}\in[20,230] (MFLOPS). Lastly, we calculate the number of image processing per second (IPS) by the following metric:

IPS=Rpeak​ [MFLOPS/sec]Computational Cost per Image [MFLOPS].IPSsubscriptRpeak [MFLOPS/sec]Computational Cost per Image [MFLOPS]\text{IPS}=\frac{\textsf{R}_{\textsf{peak}}\textsf{\leavevmode\nobreak\ [MFLOPS/sec]}}{\textsf{Computational Cost per Image [MFLOPS]}}. (26)

Fig. 10 shows IPS of multi-width configurations in log-scale, and RpeaksubscriptRpeak\textsf{R}_{\textsf{peak}} over time. As shown in Fig. 10, five different RpeaksubscriptRpeak\textsf{R}_{\textsf{peak}} phases exist. Suppose that the mobile devices require 100 images per second, i.e., IPStarget=100subscriptIPStarget100\text{IPS}_{\textit{target}}=100 marked as the yellow dashed line. In phase I in Fig. 10, the IPS requirement is only satisfied when using SNN-1/6x. In phase II, the IPS requirement is satisfied when using SNN-1/6x and SNN-2/6x. However, it is recommended to use SNN-2/6x, because the top-1 accuracy increases 4.7%. Similarly, SNN-3/6x, SNN-4/6x are recommended to be used in phase III, and phase IV, and V, respectively. Furthermore, we can use six model configurations with the memory usage of SNN-1.0x. If vanilla NN is used, 3.5x more memory is required than using SNN. Thus, using SNN is an adjustable solution for computational energy heterogeneous conditions.

VI-E Feasibility Studies on Channel and Training Environments

We investigate the generalization of SlimFL across various datasets and the different numbers of local iterations in various channel models.

VI-E1 Impact of Channel Models

We design additional simulations to verify SlimFL works in more realistic channel models (e.g., Rician fading [30] and Two-wave with diffuse power fading (TWDP) [41]). In indoor wireless communication, Rician fading is superior than Rayleigh fading. In addition, TWDP is used in air, space or maritime wireless communication, where the channel fading is worse than Rayleigh [42]. We simulate Rician fading with K𝐾K-factor 3.53.53.5, where the fading follows Rician distributions χ∼Rice​(0.5577,0.2106)similar-to𝜒Rice0.55770.2106\chi\sim\mathrm{Rice}(0.5577,0.2106). (K,Δ)𝐾Δ(K,\Delta)-factor of TWDP fading is set to (3.5,0.1)3.50.1(3.5,0.1). All communication settings without fading effect are identical to Table II. Fig. 11 is the result of the simulation. As shown in Fig. 11, the top-1 accuracy is found to be high in the order of Rayleigh fading, TWDP fading, and Rician fading channel models. SlimFL-1.0x always outperforms SlimFL-0.5x. Thus, SlimFL performs well in a variety of channel models.

VI-E2 Impact of Datasets

We conduct additional simulations to verify whether SlimFL operates with other datasets (e.g., CIFAR10 [43] and MNIST [44]). CIFAR10 dataset consists of 60,000 color images with size 32×32323232\times 32. MNIST is a handwritten digit classification dataset. It consists of 60,000 grayscale images with size 28×28282828\times 28. Both image datasets have 101010 classes, i.e., digits. CIFAR10 is known to be a more challenging problem, which is harder than MNIST or FMNIST. The simulation is conducted with α=1.0,K=10formulae-sequence𝛼1.0𝐾10\alpha=1.0,K=10, and σ2=−30​d​Bsuperscript𝜎230dB\sigma^{2}=-30\mathrm{dB}. Fig. 12 is the result of the simulation. SlimFL with MNIST dataset shows the best top-1 accuracy, FMNIST data set shows the next highest accuracy, and CIFAR10 shows the lowest accuracy. In terms of the performance between 1.0x and 0.5x, SlimFL-1.0x is always higher than SlimFL-0.5x. In other words, we confirm that our proposed SlimFL works well regardless of the dataset.

VI-E3 Impact of Local Training Iterations

This paper adopts local iterations per communication round as 111 for mathematical tractability. Thus, the convergence bound does not contain the local iteration. According to [33], the over-small or over-large local iterations cause high communication and computational cost, while the optimal local iteration exists. We conduct additional simulations to verify the SlimFL operation under different numbers of local iterations (i.e., 111, 222, 555, 101010, and 202020). As mentioned above, FedAvg does not guarantee that many local iterations are proportional to the performance [32]. Similarly in our simulation as shown in Fig. 13, the top-1 accuracy of both SlimFL-1.0x and SlimFL-0.5x is high and is on the order of {5,20,2,10,1}5202101\{5,20,2,10,1\}. The empirical result shows that there exist at least two local extremums. One is located in [2,10]210[2,10], and the other is in [5,∞]5[5,\infty], respectively. In other words, there are at least two local optima corresponding to local iterations in [1,∞]1[1,\infty]. Note that these local optima do not indicate global optima.

VII Concluding Remarks

Existing FL solutions are incapable of adjusting flexibly to devices with varying amounts of available energy and channel throughput without jeopardizing communication or energy efficiency. To overcome this problem, we propose SlimFL, a novel framework for FL over SNNs that utilizes superpositioned training for local SNN training and superposition coding for trained model aggregation. Extensive analyses and simulations show that SlimFL is an energy- and communication-efficient solution in a variety of communication conditions and data distributions. SlimFL achieves higher accuracy and faster convergence while using less energy than vanilla FL, which requires 2X more communication resources. Additionally, studying the impact of more adjustable SNN width levels could be an interesting topic for future work. Another interesting direction is to apply SlimFL for multitask learning with various width configurations in different tasks.

Appendix A Proof of Theorem 1

A-C Completing the Proof of Theorem 1

Proof.

Δt+1≤(1−μ​ηt)​Δt+ηt2​B.subscriptΔ𝑡11𝜇subscript𝜂𝑡subscriptΔ𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡2𝐵\Delta_{t+1}\leq\left(1-\mu\eta_{t}\right)\Delta_{t}+\eta_{t}^{2}{B}. (38)

By induction, we aim to show that Δt≤vt+2​κ−1subscriptΔ𝑡𝑣𝑡2𝜅1\Delta_{t}\leq\frac{v}{t+2\kappa-1} where κ=Lμ𝜅𝐿𝜇\kappa=\frac{L}{\mu} and v=max⁡{2​κ​Δ1,4​B/μ2}𝑣2𝜅subscriptΔ14𝐵superscript𝜇2v=\max\{2\kappa\Delta_{1},{4B}/{\mu^{2}}\} as elaborated next. ≤(1−2t′+2​κ−1)​vt′+2​κ−1+4​B/μ2(t′+2​κ−1)2absent12superscript𝑡′2𝜅1𝑣superscript𝑡′2𝜅14𝐵superscript𝜇2superscriptsuperscript𝑡′2𝜅12\displaystyle\leq\left(1-\frac{2}{t^{\prime}+2\kappa-1}\right)\frac{v}{t^{\prime}+2\kappa-1}+\frac{{4B}/{\mu^{2}}}{(t^{\prime}+2\kappa-1)^{2}} (40)
=(t′+2​κ−2)​v−(v−4​B/μ2)(t′+2​κ−1)2absentsuperscript𝑡′2𝜅2𝑣𝑣4𝐵superscript𝜇2superscriptsuperscript𝑡′2𝜅12\displaystyle=\frac{(t^{\prime}+2\kappa-2)v-(v-{4B}/{\mu^{2}})}{(t^{\prime}+2\kappa-1)^{2}} (41)
